p: The prevalence of metabolic syndrome (MetS), a cluster of interrelated metabolic disorders, has been on the rise globally. The International Diabetes Federation estimated that 25% of the global adult population has MetS, and its prevalence is predicted to increase in the next few decades [ 1]. The rise in the prevalence of MetS poses a serious public health burden, especially in resource-limited countries in sub-Saharan Africa [ 2]. Several billions of dollars have already been spent by governments in developing countries to curb the widespread effects of MetS and associated risk factors [ 3].
